title.narrative: Resilience to child malnutrition ACF DRC 2017-2020
Resiliens till barn undernäring ACF DRK 2017-2020

description.narrative: ACF's project objective is to sustainably strengthen nutrition security and malnutrition resilience at health system and household level in Kalomba Health Zone in Kasaï Central province in DRC, from April 2017 to March 2020, through a gender-sensitive, community-based approach. The project is articulated along two axis: the health system and the community. It includes three result areas: 1. Integrated health system structural reinforcement for sustainable nutrition service delivery; 2. Reinforced health staff capacity for intake and outreach through a gender-sensitive nutrition security approach; 3. Improved nutrition security at community and household levels through gender-sensitive behaviour change, potable water access and livelihoods support.

Insatsen har som målsättning att förebygga undernäring hos barn, samt hos gravida och ammande kvinnor, i Kalomba hälsozonen, DRK, Kasai Central under 2017-2020, genom stöd till det lokala hälsosystemet, vatten och sanitet, nutrition och livsmedelsförsörjningsstöd. Projektet stödjer hela hälsozonsbefolkningen, 157,000 personer. Stödet länkas samman med en humanitärt finansierad insats (52040469) som Action Contre la Faim (ACF) implementerat under 2014 till 2017 i Kalomba.

To prevent child malnutrition in Kalomba health zone, DRC, Kasaï Central, during 2017-2020, through water and sanitation, nutrition and support to livelihoods, and by mainstreaming gender and environment. Linked to a previous humanitarian support in 2014-2017.

tag.narrative: 2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The project has been successful with a number of tangible results such as: - Farmer Field Schools (FFS)As per the Farmer Field Schools (FFS) activities, lands were identified with FFS members and secured by signing provisional transfer of agricultural plots to avoid tensions and stock crops. 18 seeds (instead of 40) seeds banks are operational and gather differents villages including some not initially targeted by FFS activities. Up to 5,205 individuals, including 2,862 women have directly benefitted from FFS activities. 1,856 communities members have been sensitized on market gardening, small farming, crops management, and agricultural practices. As a result, - WASH improvement in health facilities: 14 health facilities, including 13 health centers and 1 hospital, have benefitted from WASH infrastructures construction - WASH in communities: 5,255 individuals have improved their access to sanitation infrastructure through the construction of 1,051 family latrines and the development of 25 waters sources has improved access to safe water for 6,455 households (i.e. 37,701 individuals – including 20;005 women and girls and 17,696 men and boys). A total of 171,900 individuals have indirectly benefitted from agricultural and nutritional improvement activities.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
